results.title: Tom Arthur
results.creator_credit: National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Tom Arthur’s art is for him a visual way of reasoning. By using the associated symbolic meanings and cultural connotations attached to specific objects and images he attempts to examine and question belief structures and systems of knowledge and how society forces these into its members. For Tom Arthur there are no absolutes, and everything seems relative

results.title: Ivan Durrant (D)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Australian artist Ivan Durrant is infamously known for killing a cow and depositing it at the entrance of the National Gallery of Victoria in the late 60’s. It was to accompany another of his well-known art pieces, “The Butcher Shop”, housed at the gallery in their permanent collection. One of Australia’s most accomplished photo-realist artists, Durrant’s paintings are featured alongside his sculptural works in this documentary. His subjects stem from childhood memories and mostly centre around images of cattle and pigs, with man’s violence against animals featuring in more esoteric ways in works like, “the quality meat show”. Looking broadly, his work is preoccupied with perception and how we choose to box or see things, or refuse to consider the more difficult truths about ourselves. Contained within this video are some images of cruelty against animals, with excerpts from Durrant’s film “Chopping Blocks” that is particularly disturbing in content. Please note: both U-matic and VHS copy have poor quality sound.

One of Australia’s most accomplished photo-realist artists, Durrant’s paintings are featured alongside his sculptural works in this documentary. His subjects stem from childhood memories and mostly centre around images of cattle and pigs, with man’s violence against animals featuring in more esoteric ways in works like, “the quality meat show”. Looking broadly, his work is preoccupied with perception and how we choose to box or see things, or refuse to consider the more difficult truths about ourselves. Contained within this video are some images of cruelty against animals, with excerpts from Durrant’s film “Chopping Blocks” that is particularly disturbing in content. His subjects stem from childhood memories and mostly centre around images of cattle and pigs, with man’s violence against animals featuring in more esoteric ways in works like, “the quality meat show”. Looking broadly, his work is preoccupied with perception and how we choose to box or see things, or refuse to consider the more difficult truths about ourselves. Contained within this video are some images of cruelty against animals, with excerpts from Durrant’s film “Chopping Blocks” that is particularly disturbing in content. results.title: A Cook's tour
results.creator_credit: Bryan Chipperfield, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Bryan Chipperfield saw no action during his service in the air force. Posted to Calgary in Canada, Chipperfield was able to enjoy skiing, boating and playing sports. Keeping up to date with the war through reading the paper, he knew he may be asked to ‘play his part’ at any time.

Read by fellow veteran Bill Medlyn for Bryan Chipperfield

results.title: John Lethbridge
results.creator_credit: Robert Lindsay, Judi Stack, Bob Weis, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
John Lethbridge’s works, his paintings, drawings and sculptural installations develop out of a personal necessity to try to give an order to the rituals and repeating experiences of life that recur in an apparently unordered and random world. His recent work can be described as “Post Conceptual Romanticism”

results.title: Martin Sharp
results.creator_credit: Andrew Scollo, Ken Otton, Robert Lindsay, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Part of a series which looks at individual artists and their works. Martin Sharp discusses his beginnings as a cartoonist for Oz magazine in the sixties and his many styles of painting. Sharp’s art has always reflected the concerns of his own personal world and in that sense is highly diaristic, recording images people and objects that have contributed to his perception of the world.

results.title: Rosalie Gascoigne
results.creator_credit: Robert Lindsay, Judi Stack, Bob Weis, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Rosalie Gascoigne talks about her work and interests. She is a self-taught assemblage artist who uses weathered, discarded junk from man-made objects and found objects from nature. Her assemblages create images of domestic country kitchens while her late installations have an outdoor open feeling for country air and light

results.title: Robert Boynes
results.creator_credit: Ken Otton, Robert Lindsay, Lloyd Carrick and Alan Cole
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Robert Boynes is often grouped with a number of Australian artists who, working from the mid 1960’s, are referred to as “Australian Pop” artists. Australian pop has its own distinct flavour, different from the U.S. and U.K. schools, and related to the Australian environment

results.title: Survey 12: on paper
results.creator_credit: Ray Harris, Michael Bongiovanni, Andrew Scollo, Robert Lindsay and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Part of a series which looks at individual artists and their works. This program interviews four artists, Micky Allan, Mandy Martin, Sally Robinson and Jenny Watson. Each artist discusses their philosophies, influences, subject matter, background in art, methods, materials and work. Each has been influenced by or incorporates photography in their work.

Each artist discusses their philosophies, influences, subject matter, background in art, methods, materials and work. Each has been influenced by or incorporates photography in their work.

results.title: Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)
results.creator_credit: Robert Lindsay, Bob Weis, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: In 1980 a series of Survey exhibitions was presented at the National Gallery of Victoria. These videos were produced as an introduction to the work of the individual artists represented in the exhibitions.
